result.execSummary:
The defendant Paul M. Hamm was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take (<=$500), a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Portage County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Huber privileges are granted pursuant to Sec. 303.08(1) Stats. and subject to the rules of the Portage County Sheriff's Department. - Stayed

miscConds.notes: Pay costs.   If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Follow any recommendations which the agent may have with respect to counseling as recommended by the agent. 
Write a very brief letter of apology to Copps Store. 
Court permits early discharge in the event the agent would approve.

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Paul M. Hamm in court with attorney Leon Stanley Schmidt. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
8:40 a.m.  Court calls the case. 

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of:  Counts 1 & 2 - NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Counts 1 & 2.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 3 is dismissed and read-in. 

Atty Schmidt makes statements to clarify. 
Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Schmidt makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Knaapen makes additional arguments to the Court. 
Atty Schmidt makes additional arguments to the Court. 
Defendant makes statements to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
75 days jail on each count, concurrent to each other.  STAYED
Entitled to huber. 
Placed on probation for a period of 18 months: 
Maintain fulltime employment. 
Follow any recommendations which the agent may have with respect to counseling as recommended by the agent. 
Write a very brief letter of apology to Copps Store. 
Pay costs.  
Court permits early discharge in the event the agent would approve.
